hero.copy: In 1903, on the corner of 17th and McGavock, the Addison Ave. Cumberland Presbyterian Church built a beautiful brick sanctuary. In 1968, Fred Foster, founder of Monument Records, purchased the church and converted it into a recording studio. In 2012, Zac Brown bought the same building and transformed it into a first-class facility that inspires creation and satisfies the appetites of artists and musicians from around the world.

readMore.title: Making Music History, Where Music History was Made.
copy: In 2012, Southern Ground was searching for a small studio space in Nashville to record and produce records for Southern Ground Artists. When we stumbled upon the site that would later become our home, we couldn't have fathomed the rich, musical history that had lived here for just over a century.

Located at the foot of Nashville's music row, the building that houses Southern Ground Nashville was originally built between 1897 and 1903, and served as the Addison Avenue Cumberland Presbyterian Church until the mid-1950s.

After a brief stint as a VFW Post, the facility was purchased by Fred Foster, owner of famed recording company Monument Records, and transformed into Monument Studio in 1968. Managed at the time by now-legendary engineers Mort Thomassen and Tommy Strong, many fabled country recordings were produced in this era, including Kris Kristofferson's first three albums.

In 1975, the studio was purchased by Chip Young, renamed Young'un Sound and permitted to continue its tradition of pumping out classic Nashville recordings well into the 1980s. Later, Al Jolson, Jr., son of the famous performer Al Jolson, purchased the studio and dubbed it with yet another new moniker: Masterlink Studio. It was during this era that the building transformed into a high-tech facility specializing in audio for video remixing, including mixes for TNN (Hee Haw, CMT, etc.)

In the 1990s and 2000s, the walls of Masterlink witnessed a number of celebrated recordings, including that of Neil Young's "Prairie Wind" album. But due to his ailing health, Jolson was forced to shut the studio down in 2010. It sat vacant for nearly two years, and, at one point, was in serious danger of becoming a Mexican restaurant.

When Southern Ground acquired the studio in 2012, we began by renovating the now 100-year-old building to restore much of its original character.  A Mix room was also added that includes an SSL 4000G+ console ATC 300's and a small overdub space.

We were also lucky enough to inherit some of the classic recording gear that Masterlink left behind, including a Neve V3, 48 tracks of 2" analog tape, Ampex ATR-102 master 2-track recorder and vintage Neumann U47/U48 microphones (perhaps better known as The Beatles microphone).

Thanks to our new location, incredible on-site talent and the impeccable taste in recording equipment of those who came before us, we now have the ability to efficiently produce albums from start to finish, using a hybrid of classic analog and modern digital technology, all under one roof.

questions.question: Position at Southern Ground Nashville
questions.answer: Studio Director

questions.question: Originally from
questions.answer: Visalia, California

questions.question: How you got to Nashville
questions.answer: I came to Nashville to join a band. The band didn't work out, but it led to many other fantastic opportunities that made me decide to stay.

questions.question: How you got to SGN
questions.answer: I was working for Zac's record label, making records in my basement studio. The time came for the operation to grow, and I helped Zac find the facility and open the studio.

questions.question: Favorite Studio Mama Creation
questions.answer: Levi Chicken followed by pound cake. Actually, forget the chicken - I'll just have the pound cake.

questions.question: Like most about SGN
questions.answer: The studio is a home away from home. Every single bit of this place was made with love, especially the love for music, art, and the preservation of their history.

questions.question: Best part of your job
questions.answer: Working with my co-workers. Not only are they immensely talented in their craft, they are fiercely committed to doing whatever it takes to get the job done.

questions.question: Fave piece of gear/equipment
questions.answer: Ampex ATR-102.

questions.question: Hidden Talents?
questions.answer: I can juggle.

questions.question: Hobbies?
questions.answer: Gardening and mindlessly reading Wikipedia entries.

questions.question: Best Dollar store purchase?
questions.answer: Official Darth Vader Key Chain.

questions.question: Position at Southern Ground Nashville
questions.answer: Studio Mama

questions.question: Originally from
questions.answer: Columbus, Georgia

questions.question: How you got to Nashville
questions.answer: In April of 2012, my family visited Nashville over Spring Break, while The Wood Brothers (my husband’s band) were working on a project.  We visited the studio at that time since the band was on the Southern Ground label at the time.  We all fell in love with the city.  Oliver and I went back to Atlanta after spending a week here and decided to consider moving.  We moved into a rental house sight-unseen that very July.

questions.question: How you got to SGN
questions.answer: After the adventure of moving fairly suddenly, getting the kids registered for school, and unpacking our lives, I set to the adventure of finding work. I sent my resume to nearly every contact I had and did some cold-calling. One afternoon, I decided to send my resume to Zac, knowing that he’d have plenty of contacts in Nashville. He then forwarded it to Matt Mangano, the studio’s Director, since the studio was just getting ready for regular use. Matt hired me, neither of us knowing exactly what the job was going to be.  I’ve loved every day here since!!

questions.question: Favorite Studio Mama Creation
questions.answer: Levi Lowry Chicken (chicken leg quarters marinated in a mix of soy sauce, orange marmalade, fresh ginger, and mustard powder) with brown rice and stir fry vegetables.  Poundcake or Blackberry Cobbler.

questions.question: Like most about SGN
questions.answer: The smell of wood and baked goods.

questions.question: Best part of your job
questions.answer: This job allows me to wear all my best hats. I equally enjoy the personal and professional relationships I build and the days I get to spend at my desk doing expense reports and booking.

questions.question: Fave piece of gear/equipment
questions.answer: CAST IRON SKILLETS!

questions.question: Hidden Talents?
questions.answer: Building crafty puppets, lanterns, and putting together crazy costumes for my Krewe of the Grateful Gluttons events in Atlanta.

questions.question: Hobbies?
questions.answer: Cooking, baking, crafting, good whiskey.

questions.question: Best Dollar store purchase?
questions.answer: Glowsticks, duh.

questions.question: Position at Southern Ground Nashville
questions.answer: Engineer

questions.question: Originally from
questions.answer: Boulder, Colorado

questions.question: How you got to Nashville
questions.answer: As far as cities go, Nashville is really laid back. Coming from a more rural upbringing larger music cities like New York or Los Angeles never seemed like a good fit for me. Also, the musical talent in this town is incredible. Most of the musicians I grew up idolizing worked here in Nashville.

questions.question: How you got to SGN
questions.answer: I stumbled onto a small information website related to Southern Ground Nashville while attending college in Boston. I immediatley recognized that it was special, and the only place I wanted to be. After leaving Boston I trusted that instict and was fortunate enough to be in the right place at the right time.

questions.question: Favorite Studio Mama Creation
questions.answer: Spaghetti & meatballs is my current favorite. Also, anytime she gets to baking, work in the studio comes to a screeching halt. It’s amazing.

questions.question: Like most about SGN
questions.answer: Southern Ground is a place people can feel comfortable and enjoy time spent working or hanging out. There’s a quality and an integrity that isn’t available just anywhere. The atmosphere, hospitality, not to mention anything you could possibly desire technologically speaking, make this studio second to none.

questions.question: Best part of your job
questions.answer: Nashville is one of the most musically brilliant communities in the world, and in moving here my mission statement was simple; find ways to get involved and contribute. Not everyone has the privelage of doing that. I’ve been blessed to work with so many immensley talented musicians, producers, and engineers. Being a part of the musical community here in Nashville has been surreal, and I have my friends at Southern Ground to thank for that opportunity.

questions.question: Fave piece of gear/equipment
questions.answer: All of our vintage Martin, Gibson, and Fender guitars.

questions.question: Hidden Talents?
questions.answer: My yodeling melts faces.

questions.question: Hobbies?
questions.answer: Snowboarding, hockey, turning Wrenches on old cars, and watching Tarantino flicks.

questions.question: Best Dollar store purchase?
questions.answer: Whoopi Cushion.
